Award.AwardTitle: Planning I/UCRC University of Michigan Ann Arbor: Center for High Pressure Plasma Energy, Agriculture, and Biomedical Technologies (PEAB)
Award.AbstractNarration:
Low Temperature non-equilibrium Plasma (LTP) science provides a base technology on which many modern industries, such as microelectronics and materials fabrication, have been built. Plasmas are ionized gases which can be activated with electric fields which energize electrons. Through electron collisions with molecules, LTPs are able to efficiently generate chemically reactive gases, which in turn create new functionality through creating new compounds or adding/removing material from surfaces. Recent breakthroughs in plasma-generating electronics have made it possible to develop novel systems to widen the area of LTP applications at atmospheric and higher pressures (even in liquids) to utilize this chemical reactivity. This new ability has stimulated the interest of industries such as food processing, agriculture, fuel conversion medical, water treatment, and pharmaceutical industries to apply LTPs to improve the efficiency of processing or create new processes. The use of LTPs in these industries for advanced technologies is now restricted by limited scientific understanding of the fundamental underpinnings of the applications.

Drexel University and the University of Michigan are planning to establish a National Science Foundation Industry/University Cooperative Research Center (I/UCRC) that focuses on leveraging the chemical activation power of LTPs to new technologies. The academic researchers in the Center will investigate the fundamental scientific basis of LTPs as used in the energy, environmental remediation, water treatment, food safety and processing, and medical and bioengineering sectors. Through collaboration with industrial members of the Center, these fundamental principles will be translated into improving and creating new technologies to address the food-water-energy nexus and to improve human health. In addition to helping to enable industry to address critical societal needs, these improvements in technology will create economic opportunities.

Institution.Name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Planning I/UCRC University of Michigan Ann Arbor: Center for High Pressure Plasma Energy, Agriculture, and Biomedical Technologies (PEAB) grant was used to organize a meeting whose chief focus was to assess industry needs in the areas of water treatment, medicine and agriculture, to solicit industry feedback based on presentations to interested industrial parties, and to refine/focus the Center's scope.  The Center includes the University of Michigan, whose focus is on water, George Washington University whose focus is on plasma medicine, and Drexel University, whose focus is on plasma agriculture.   Based on industrial feedback,  an outcome of this planning meeting refined the focus of University of Michigan effort to include 1) plasma droplet interactions for the purpose of activation, 2) plasma interaction with biological material supporting plasma medicine, and 3) plasma water interaction supporting water purification.  These tasks adddress societal problems and challenges. The research thrusts are cross cutting and complementary with each tasks under study by George Washington and Drexel University.   Task 1 addresses plasma activated water for sterilization for medical applications as well as the fertilzation of plants for agricultural applications.  Task 2 addresses the interaction of plasma activated water with biological tissue to better understand plasma wound healing as well as plasma treatment of cancerous tumors.  Task 3 addresses the development of efficient, high throughput plasma sources for the purpose of drinking water treatment, removing contaminants of emerging concern.  The University of Michigan thrust area is unique in that in additition to experimenal efforts, it utilizes inhouse computational tools to supporti modeling efforts for each of the center partners. The Planning meeting also estalished the framework for workforce development in the area of plasma engineering. Here the plan for the involvement of students via direct research at the Center as well as internships at the various industrial partner sites was formulated. Finally, the planning activity allowed for the identification of 15 companies interested in joining the Center ranging from water treatment, to medical to semiconductor manufacturing.  Each company brings with them insight into future technological issues and concerns that must be addressed to assure world competitiveness. These problems will serve as the raw materials for research and development to be carried on at the center. The Center therefore is reponsive to not only societally impactful problem solving but also research efforts that improve as a whole this Country's ecomonmic competitiveness.

 


Last Modified: 04/02/2018
Modified by: John E Foster
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The Planning I/UCRC University of Michigan Ann Arbor: Center for High Pressure Plasma Energy, Agriculture, and Biomedical Technologies (PEAB) grant was used to organize a meeting whose chief focus was to assess industry needs in the areas of water treatment, medicine and agriculture, to solicit industry feedback based on presentations to interested industrial parties, and to refine/focus the Center's scope. The Center includes the University of Michigan, whose focus is on water, George Washington University whose focus is on plasma medicine, and Drexel University, whose focus is on plasma agriculture. Based on industrial feedback, an outcome of this planning meeting refined the focus of University of Michigan effort to include 1) plasma droplet interactions for the purpose of activation, 2) plasma interaction with biological material supporting plasma medicine, and 3) plasma water interaction supporting water purification. These tasks adddress societal problems and challenges. The research thrusts are cross cutting and complementary with each tasks under study by George Washington and Drexel University. Task 1 addresses plasma activated water for sterilization for medical applications as well as the fertilzation of plants for agricultural applications. Task 2 addresses the interaction of plasma activated water with biological tissue to better understand plasma wound healing as well as plasma treatment of cancerous tumors. Task 3 addresses the development of efficient, high throughput plasma sources for the purpose of drinking water treatment, removing contaminants of emerging concern. The University of Michigan thrust area is unique in that in additition to experimenal efforts, it utilizes inhouse computational tools to supporti modeling efforts for each of the center partners. The Planning meeting also estalished the framework for workforce development in the area of plasma engineering. Here the plan for the involvement of students via direct research at the Center as well as internships at the various industrial partner sites was formulated. Finally, the planning activity allowed for the identification of 15 companies interested in joining the Center ranging from water treatment, to medical to semiconductor manufacturing. Each company brings with them insight into future technological issues and concerns that must be addressed to assure world competitiveness. These problems will serve as the raw materials for research and development to be carried on at the center. The Center therefore is reponsive to not only societally impactful problem solving but also research efforts that improve as a whole this Country's ecomonmic competitiveness.
